measure_explanation:
The rate of UK unemployment as a percentage of the potential labour force.  

 Unemployed people are those without a job who have been actively seeking work in the past 4 weeks and are available to start work in the next 2 weeks. It also includes those who are out of work but have found a job and are waiting to start it in the next 2 weeks. Find out more about how unemployment is measured.  

 The rate of UK unemployment are measured by the Labour Force Survey (LFS) using a definition of unemployment specified by the International Labour Organisation.
overall_summary:
Unemployment has decreased over the past three years for most groups, with the exception of Indian and other Asian people, who have seen a small increase in unemployment. Younger people across all backgrounds have a significantly higher rate of unemployment.  

 In 2015, ethnic minorities have higher rates of unemployment, with people from a black background having the highest unemployment rate at 14%.  

 Whilst unemployment for both men and women is just above 5% in the UK, black men are more likely to be unemployed than black women, and Pakistani or Bangladeshi women are far more likely to be unemployed than Pakistani or Bangladeshi men.  

 Read the [further information and guidance](http://localhost:3000/attainment8/metadata) about the data in the tables.
